content.description:
This is a line between

Streak of Bad Luck

and

Chokin' the Chickenhead

that is as thin as it looks...and maybe more.

The start is thin and crumbly right after you get established.  (I'm told that the line was changed in the interim and is more direct.) Aim for a hole, the last good hold for a while.  Fight, scratch, and kick to keep moving upward.  Staying right, at times, all you seem to get is two marginal undercling pinches.  Staying left slightly, you may suss out some slightly better options.  Finally, on the last third of the route, you get some positive holds.  Finish at the anchors.

Previously, it appears that someone may have considered equipping it with bolts, since there is at least 1 drilled hole on the route.  Now it sports bolts.

Rich Perch rated this 5.10.
content.protection:
This route now sports 5 bolts

and now its own anchors

.  Clip 'em or TR it.  Originally, this shared anchors with

Streak of Bad Luck

.
content.location:
This is between

Streak of Bad Luck

and

Chokin' the Chickenhead

.  This is the 4th bolted route from the right.

climbs.name: Streak of Bad Luck
climbs.fa: Rich Perch, Dan Hare, Tom Kohlman, 7/31/9

content.description:
This is currently the now the 5th route from the right (4th from the left) up this aspen-ed gully.  It has a few slightly off balance bits.

Chase 4 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor.

Rap 30'.

Rich Perch rated this 5.9.
content.location: This is currently the 5th route from the right (4th from the left) up this aspen-ed gully.

content.description:
This is the leftmost route up this gully (the aspen filled gully on the lowest part of the formation facing the road) on the right side of this crag. The rock is definitely scaly and scruffy.  Too bad, because the moves could be fun.  Decent-sized holds are still coming off this route.

Get stable on the face, reach out right to an edge, grab the rounded jug left, clip.  Now you get the crux move where you get your feet up on scaly rock, paste, pull, and deadpoint.  The crunching under foot is disquieting.  The difficulty eases, but the rock quality remains suspect.  Move left after the 3rd bolt.

Rappel 25'.

Rich Perch rates this 5.10.
content.protection: 3 bolts, a spot, 2 bolt anchor with twisted links.
content.location: This is the leftmost / highest bolted climb up this aspen-ed gully.

climbs.name: Pickup Line
climbs.fa: a rodent, bolted by Dan Hare & Rich Perch, 9/11

content.description:
This is line was done as a TR originally and now sports bolts.

Ascend a delicate, low angle slab past 3 bolts.  The climbing is thin but enjoyable for its first half.  The second half has much more moderate terrain.

The original name, Tubsy, came from a pet Robo dwarf hamster of Kira's.  Upon request, she was willing to let it be renamed to the above name, requested by Rich Perch.
content.protection: 3 bolts, optional cam, 2 bolt anchor with rings shared with Ascent of a Woman.
content.location:
This is just left of

Ascent of a Woman

.

content.description:
This is a nice addition to the Quickie Cliff at the lower end of difficulty.  It ascends near vertical rock with generous holds and a few bulges.  It may perplex the true beginner above the 3rd bolt, don't stray too far right.  Height isn't necessary, a 4'6" climber shot right up it.

Rich Perch rated it 5.7, but the kids called it pretty easy.
content.protection:
5 bolts, 2 bolt anchor with rings shared with

Atrophied Husband

.
content.location: This is the rightmost route at the crag.  It starts just right of a pine that is very close to the rock.

content.description:
This is the 2nd climb from the left up this aspen-ed gully.  It is probably harder for those 5'6" or less.

Don't go right after the 3rd bolt, there may be a decent-sized loose block up there.

Move up into a bird bath scoop.  For the shorter folks, this is the crux.  You must keep your feet on well enough on somewhat scaly rock to reach up and grab some positive edges.  For those 5'10" or more, this will be straightforward.  At the 3rd bolt, go left to the anchors.

Rappel 25'.

Rich Perch rated this 5.8.  Deb called it 5.7.  The word is that many think it is 5.9...so be ready.
content.protection: 3 bolts, 2 bolt anchor with twisted links.
content.location: This is the second from the left / second highest bolted climb up this aspen-ed gully.

content.description:
This is a fun, short, boy's route.  It is the 3rd from the left up this aspen-ed gully and is characterized by a bulge.  Too bad it doesn't go on for another 100 feet....

Pull aboard on jugs.  Choose your jug sequence.  At the second bolt, again you get a choice, boys go left, girls go right.  Darn, the anchors come too soon.

Rap 25'.

Rich Perch rated this 5.9.  Deb rated it 5.8.
content.protection: 3 bolts, 2 Metolius rap bolt anchor (which can threaded directly).
content.location: This is the 3rd from the left (now 6th from the right) of the bolted climbs up this aspen-ed gully.

content.description:
This is a good line that stays fairly sustained and interesting for its upper two-thirds, but it suffers a bit from the crumbliness of the lower band of this cliff.

Angle up and right to start, reach back left to clip, move up to clip the 2nd bolt, and move left on tenuous holds.  Pull up and onto the upper face, keep in balance, and enjoy the engaging sequences almost all the way to the anchors.
content.location: This is currently the third route from the right on the Quickie Cliff.

content.description:
This is the leftmost bolted line on the easterly aspect of this small crag.  It is quite low angled, and as a result, with some extra preparation, it can make for a good introduction to leading for the budding climber.

The start is probably the crux with gritty feet on rounded, coarse granite and a mantle thrown in.  Above the 1st bolt, one can get a good #0.5 Camalot.  Chase 3 more bolts to a 2 bolt anchor.

Rappel 45'.

Rich Perch indicates this is 5.6, hence the name.

There is also a 5.4 start to the left which is called Four Play.
content.protection:
4 bolts,

#0.5 Camalot

, 2 bolt anchor with rings.
content.location: This is the leftmost bolted route on the easterly aspect of this crag.

content.description:
This is a nice line that has some sustained, interesting climbing after a currently crumbly start.

Pull up onto the face.  Pay attention at the start, since the lower band of this cliff is not too consolidated.  The crux comes low as you pull onto the featured, more solid face above.  There are two ways to solve this crux, left or right. Continue up on interesting knobs.  The last 20 feet are on low angle terrain.  The anchors are shared with

Manly Bulge

.
content.protection:
6 bolts, 2 bolt anchor share with

Manly Bulge

.
content.location:
This is the second bolted route from the right on the Quickie Cliff's right face.  It is just left of

Manly Bulge

, 6.

climbs.name: Ascent of a Woman
climbs.fa: Sue Day, Roger Truesdale, and Byron Prinzemetal, 7/3/11

content.description:
This is the right slab, 3rd bolted line from the left, on the easterly aspect of this crag.  It starts up a low angled face and slabs out 2/3'rds the way up.

Climb up on gentle terrain.  At about the 3rd bolt, you may find a crux.  There are 2 ways to go, left or right.  Going left may be easier if you are tall.  After the 4th bolt, the terrain gets even lower angle.  You can place a #2 Camalot and possibly a yellow or orange TCU.

Rappel 45'.

This route shares an anchor with

Tubsy

.

Rich Perch indicates this is 5.8.
content.protection:
4 bolts, #2 Camalot, possibly yellow or orange TCU, 2 bolt anchor with rings shared with

Pickup Line

.
content.location: This is the 3rd bolted line from the left on the easterly aspect of this crag.
